intro: Alona balsamiflua, commonly known as the balsam poppy, is a flowering plant native to the western United States. It is characterized by its striking, showy flowers that range in color from white to pink and red. The plant has narrow, lance-shaped leaves that are often covered in a fine, silky hair. It thrives in well-drained soils and full sun, typically found in dry, open habitats. Alona balsamiflua is a member of the Papaveraceae family, which includes other poppies and related species.
